prompts: Write a 5-7-5 haiku about a mossy forest just after rain, focusing on the scent of wet earth and the hush beneath the pines.
Compose a traditional nature haiku about a winter sunrise over a frozen lake—pale light, breath in the air, and a distant crow.

Write a Shakespearean sonnet for my partner, Mia, for our 5th anniversary. Include references to the summer we met on a stormy beach in Cornwall, her love of astronomy (Orion and moonlight), and the rough patch we overcame last winter. Keep the ABAB CDCD EFEF GG rhyme scheme and end on a hopeful, tender couplet.

Compose a romantic sonnet about a long-distance relationship: I’m in Chicago and my boyfriend, Arjun, is in Mumbai. Please weave in late-night video calls, mismatched time zones, monsoon rain, Lake Michigan winds, and the scent of cardamom chai. Use modern English, keep it in iambic pentameter, and let the volta turn on the hope of our next reunion.
Please write a funny limerick about a sleepy barista trying to tame a rebellious espresso machine at 5 a.m. Keep it light and only one limerick.
Compose a clean, humorous limerick about working from home that includes the words 'wifi', 'deadline', and 'cat'. Just one limerick, please.

Write a free-verse poem in a conversational tone about riding the last bus home through a sprawling city. Include images of flickering neon, cracked phone screens, condensation on windows, and an overheard fragment of a breakup call. End with a small, quiet moment of relief. 14–20 lines.

Compose a compressed, image-driven free-verse piece about sunrise in the financial district after an overnight storm: loading docks humming, steam rising from vents, office towers reflecting pink light, street sweepers, a lone jogger. Keep lines short; no more than 16 lines; avoid rhyme; let a calm optimism seep through.
Make an uplifting acrostic poem using the name 'MAYA' for a graduation card. Four lines only, each starting with M, A, Y, A. Keep it under 25 words total.
Can you write a playful acrostic for the name BRUNO about a goofy dog who loves snacks? One line per letter, light rhyme optional.

Compose a short ode (10–14 lines) to my favorite comfort food: my dad’s chicken noodle soup. Include sensory details like steam fogging my glasses, the clink of the spoon on the bowl, the thyme-and-garlic aroma, soft coins of carrot, wide egg noodles, and how it made sick days feel safe and warm.

Write a playful ode, one tight paragraph, to my favorite food: ripe mangoes—the skin yielding under a thumb, the sunlit perfume when it’s cut open, juice running down the wrists, a sprinkle of chili and salt, and how each bite carries me back to humid monsoon summers at my aunt’s house.

Write a ballad in four quatrains (ABCB rhyme) about Mara, a young messenger crossing three mountain passes in winter to carry a peace treaty between rival valleys. Work in images of frost, a faltering lantern, and a bridge of ice. Keep a steady, traditional ballad rhythm, and end on a quiet note of hope.

Compose a sea-shanty-style ballad, 12–16 lines, about a city bus driver who decides to keep driving beyond the route's end and discovers small acts of kindness at each stop. Include a simple, repeating refrain every fourth line: Roll on, wheels, roll on. Keep the tone warm and contemporary.

Write a 19-line villanelle on heartbreak after a long-distance relationship falls apart. Use the following two refrains exactly:
- 'I wait where departures bruise the day'
- 'your silence boards a train I cannot name'
Work in imagery of empty platforms, unsent messages, and rain on glass. Keep the tone intimate and contemporary.

Compose a villanelle about heartbreak in the aftermath of a divorce, from a parent's perspective while packing up a quiet house. Include sensory details like dust motes in late afternoon light, a creaking floorboard, and a forgotten stuffed rabbit. Let the mood be tender rather than bitter, and avoid archaic diction.

Write a short elegy (10–12 lines) for my cat, Miso, who passed away last week at 16. Details: black-and-white tuxedo, chirped instead of meowed, loved to nap in the warm laundry basket, kept me company through late-night grad school writing, adopted from a shelter when I was 12, one ear slightly torn, adored sunbeams on the kitchen floor. I’m feeling a mix of gratitude and a quiet ache. Please keep it tender, specific, and unrhymed.

Compose a brief elegy (under 180 words) as a letter to my senior dog, Rufus—a golden retriever we let go peacefully after cancer. He carried a frayed blue tennis ball everywhere, loved swimming at the lake, had a snowy white muzzle, and always waited by the door at 5 p.m. He taught my kids gentleness. Make it sincere but not saccharine, include the ball and the lake, and end on a single line about learning to walk without the leash in my hand.
Compose a tanka about early autumn in a small mountain town—crisp apples, woodsmoke at dusk, and migrating geese overhead. Keep the language simple and evocative.
Please write a tanka for summer’s first heat wave in a crowded city: shimmering asphalt, rattling window fans, and the smell of rain before a storm. Make it hopeful.
Please write a classic 2-4-6-8-2 syllable cinquain about friendship, with cozy autumn imagery (campfires, scarves, leaves).
Could you craft a word-count cinquain (1-2-3-4-1 words) on friendship based on this memory: 'Swapping gloves in the snow, laughing till our cheeks hurt'?
Write a 20- to 30-word micropoem about a bustling city at dawn, using a single extended metaphor and no punctuation.
In 45 words or less, craft a melancholy micropoem about missing someone; include the words 'key', 'window', and 'rain', and break it into three short lines.

Write a playful 8-line rhyming poem for my daughter Mia’s 5th birthday. She loves dinosaurs, purple tutus, chocolate chip pancakes, and her stuffed bunny named Nibbles. Please include her big brother Leo and our cat Whiskers, and end the poem with the exact line: “Happy 5th Birthday, Mia!”

Create a gentle bedtime-style birthday poem (4–6 short lines) for my son Arjun turning 3. He adores trucks, rain puddles, mangoes, and the moon. Mention that Nani and Dada are visiting from Delhi. Keep it sweet and simple with easy words a toddler can understand.

Please write a short apology poem for my friend Maya. I missed her first solo art show last Friday because I got stuck on a last‑minute work deadline and, worst of all, I went silent instead of texting. She’s a brilliant painter who loves late‑afternoon light and sun‑washed colors, and our regular hangout is the coffee shop called 'Bean There.' Make it 10–12 lines with a gentle rhyme scheme and soft imagery (light, paint, an empty chair). Keep the tone warm, sincere, and accountable—no grand declarations, just owning the mistake and asking for a chance to make it right (maybe coffee on me and helping hang canvases next time). End with a clear, heartfelt apology by name.

Could you craft a playful, rhyming apology poem to my friend Dev? During game night (Catan) I got salty, snapped at him, and accused him of always steamrolling the table—it wasn’t fair. Include our inside jokes about blue shells from Mario Kart and his cat, Pixel, who loves to sit on the rulebook. Keep it light but genuinely apologetic, in 8 lines of couplets (AABBCCDD). Avoid flowery language; aim for witty, friendly, and sincere.

Please write an 8–10 line rhyming thank-you poem for my 5th-grade science teacher, Ms. Lopez. She made class fun with hands-on experiments (baking-soda volcanoes, growing beans in the window), always said 'let's test it!', and stayed after school to help me understand circuits. Tone: warm, playful, and sincere. End with 'Thank you, Ms. Lopez.'

For Teacher Appreciation Week, compose three haiku to thank my high school literature teacher, Mr. Daniels. He introduced me to Shakespeare’s sonnets, scribbled thoughtful notes in the margins of my essays, and checked in on me during a rough semester. Keep the imagery bookish (ink, paper, dog-eared pages) and the mood quietly grateful.

Please write a wedding-vow-style poem I can read to my partner, Maya, during our ceremony. Keep it warm with a touch of humor, free verse, about 12–14 lines. Include: we met in a grad school library, our rescue dog Pico, my overactive smoke alarm from burnt toast, Sunday crossword rituals, our sourdough starter named “Yeats,” and rock climbing (promise to keep her safe on belay). Vows to listen first, to take the last slice of pizza only if offered, to make ordinary days our favorite. End with the line: “I choose you, now and always.”

Compose a tender, modern wedding-vow poem for my wife-to-be, Jordan (she/her), from me, Aria (she/her). Free verse, gentle and lyrical, 10–12 lines. Include: we survived long-distance between Oakland and Portland with postcards and late trains; our cat Comet; evening tea rituals; supporting her through chronic migraines (promising to honor rest and quiet days); and our ceremony under Mendocino redwoods. Sprinkle in a few Spanish words (mi hogar, juntos) naturally. Close with the line: “Te elijo.”
Write a light, upbeat get-well-soon poem for my friend Maya, who’s recovering from the flu. She loves baking sourdough and hiking. Keep it warm, a little playful, and 8–10 lines max.
Please craft a short, kid-friendly get-well poem for my 6-year-old nephew, Leo, who broke his arm. He loves dinosaurs and space rockets. Make it rhyming, cheerful, and no more than 6 lines.

Please write an acrostic motivational morning poem using the word MORNING (7 lines, each line starting with the next letter). Make it warm but energizing, aimed at a new parent running on little sleep, and include a gentle reminder to breathe.
I have a big presentation today and woke up nervous. Create a short motivational morning poem (8–10 lines, rhymed couplets) that uses ocean imagery and ends with a concise mantra I can repeat.

Write a Shakespearean sonnet that satirizes smartphone addiction by personifying push notifications as jealous lovers. Keep it playful rather than preachy, and work in the phrases 'Do Not Disturb' and 'infinite scroll.'

Give me three clean limericks poking fun at 'smart' home gadgets (fridges, lights, speakers) that constantly need firmware updates. Make the humor good-natured, and end the last limerick with a twist.

Compose a 12-line free-verse sci-fi poem about a botanist who tends an orchard aboard a centuries-long generation ship, using sensory details (scent of recycled air, LED suns, seed catalogs) and hinting at their mixed feelings about a homeworld they've never seen. Keep it under 150 words.

Create three connected haiku (5-7-5 each) that tell a brief sci-fi story: two lovers attempt to meet by skipping through time, but their jumps are always slightly misaligned. Include subtle imagery of clocks, red-shifted light, and empty train platforms.

Write a lyrical narrative poem (12–16 lines) about a one‑eyed ranger and a sardonic talking raven crossing a cursed bog to find the Lantern of Winter. Use clear ABAB rhyme, vivid sensory imagery (mist, peat, cold stars), and end on a hopeful glimmer as the lantern stirs.

Compose a short, whimsical quest poem for children (no more than 14 lines) about a baker’s apprentice who teams up with a baby dragon to return a stolen moon crumb to the Sky Queen. Keep it playful with gentle alliteration, simple end rhymes, and a cozy bedtime feel.

Write a dreamlike, surreal free-verse poem (no rhyme) in the second person about wandering through a nocturnal city where buildings are clock faces and whales drift between the streetlights. Keep it under 16 lines, focus on tactile and sound imagery, and include one quiet twist halfway through that changes the sense of time.

Compose a surreal, lullaby-soft poem in the voice of a sleepwalker who carries a teacup of moonlight. Please weave in these images: a train made of salt, a door that grows feathers, a library of warm snow, and a radio that only plays yesterday. Use 2–3 short stanzas, a gentle cadence, and repeat the line 'do not wake the water.'

Write a short Gothic mood poem (12–16 lines) set in a crumbling abbey on a cliff at midnight. Use imagery of a salt-stung wind, a shattered rose window, a wavering lantern, and a bell that tolls once. Lean into assonance and soft alliteration to create a hushed, haunted tone, with personified shadows and a theme of longing for something lost to time. Keep diction contemporary (avoid thee/thy) and aim for subtle slant rhyme.

Compose a Gothic mood poem in second person, 10–14 lines, about an abandoned forest train station after a storm. Work in recurring images of a rusted clock, ivy swallowing signage, damp moths, and an unsent letter in a cracked valise. The voice should be intimate and eerie, with sensory details (scent of wet iron, pulse of distant thunder) and a faint note of tenderness. Avoid overt horror; no jump scares, just melancholic unease.

Write a 12-line pastoral free-verse poem set in the Cotswolds at first light. Center it on dew-soaked meadow grass, skylark song, a slow-bending river, dry-stone walls, and a shepherd walking with his collie. Keep the language simple and luminous, avoid end rhyme, and close on a quiet note of gratitude.

Compose a short countryside poem (no more than 10 lines) in the mood of a folk-song refrain about late-summer hayfields and a red barn. Work in images of swallows looping, a creaking gate, the smell of cut clover, and distant church bells. Use soft internal rhyme and repeat the exact line 'and the day goes easy' at the end.

Write a short ekphrastic poem (no more than 14 lines) about Vincent van Gogh’s The Starry Night (1889): a midnight sky of cobalt and ultramarine churns with spirals of light; a dark cypress flames up at left; below, a small village with a tall church steeple sleeps under the stars. Let the voice feel restless yet tender, attentive to motion and quiet.

Compose an intimate ekphrastic poem (10–12 lines) addressed to the figure in Johannes Vermeer’s Girl with a Pearl Earring (c. 1665): she turns over her shoulder, lips parted, wearing a blue-and-gold turban, a single teardrop pearl catching the light against a dark background. Use second person, hushed and direct, noticing light, breath, and stillness.

Write a short free-verse poem (8–10 lines) from the perspective of an overdue library book stuffed in a backpack, torn between pride at being cherished and worry about late fees. Use warm, bookish imagery and end on a hopeful note.
Compose a brief poem (no more than 12 lines) from the point of view of a cracked smartphone screen that has watched its owner grow up. Blend tenderness and a touch of humor; avoid rhyme.

Write a second-person pep-talk poem for someone up late studying for finals, feeling overwhelmed but still pushing through. Make it 10 lines, present tense, and speak directly to "you." Use concrete images like a buzzing desk lamp, coffee steam, and scribbled margin notes. Keep the tone calm and encouraging, no forced rhymes. End with a final line that starts: "You can do this."

Give me a punchy second-person pep-talk poem for right before you pitch your startup on stage. Keep it 8–12 short lines, under 90 words, with strong verbs and a staccato rhythm. Avoid clichés. Include stage lights and a microphone as images. Address the reader as "you" throughout. End with the two-word line: "Go now."
Write a list poem of small joys you can find in a city morning. Keep it to 10 short lines, each line under 8 words, and include at least one sensory detail for sight, sound, and smell.
I’ve had a rough week—please craft a gentle list poem celebrating tiny home comforts on a rainy Sunday. Aim for 8–12 lines, present tense, with warm, cozy imagery and no rhymes.

Write two quatrains (8 lines total) about walking through a foggy forest at dusk. Use an ABAB rhyme scheme in each stanza, weave in sensory details (sound, smell, touch), and keep the tone contemplative yet hopeful.
Compose a lighthearted 4-line poem about a cat who thinks it’s a pirate captaining a cardboard ship. Use an ABAB rhyme scheme and include at least one nautical term.

Please craft a 9-line poem centered on 's' alliteration about a salt-sprayed seaside storm softening into sunlight. Use vivid but concrete images, avoid end rhymes, keep 5–8 words per line, and include one metaphor.
Write a playful, alliteration-heavy bedtime poem for a child about a moonlit meadow, leaning on 'm' and 'l' sounds. Keep it to 8 short lines, gentle rhythm, and end with a calming wish.

Write a short free-verse poem (8–12 lines, under 120 words) that naturally incorporates all of the following five words at least once: bramble, cinder, horizon, hollow, thimble. Set it at dusk in a quiet coastal town and give it a wistful-but-hopeful tone.

Please compose a limerick (5 lines) that includes all five of these words somewhere in the verse: algorithm, lullaby, pomegranate, rust, echo. Make it about an old desktop computer humming at night. Keep it under 70 words.

Write a dialogue-style poem where a lighthouse and the fog speak to each other about constancy and change. Use alternating lines labeled “Lighthouse:” and “Fog:”, keep it lyrical and reflective, avoid strict rhyme, and limit it to 14–18 lines with imagery of the sea and night.

Compose a playful dialogue poem between a time-traveling barista and their forgetful future self arguing over the correct coffee order. Use short back-and-forth lines labeled “Barista:” and “Future Me:”, include a light twist at the end, and keep it under 20 lines.
